newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Growing investment role seen for S.African unions.
newsitem.headline: Growing investment role seen for S.African unions.

text.p: South African trade union influence in investment markets was mushrooming through their participation in industry and employer-sponsored retirement funds, leading life assurer Old Mutual said on Monday.
"Trade unions...are becoming a force to be reckoned with in South Africa's investment markets," Old Mutual Actuaries & Consultants director Pierre Pretorius said in a statement.

The union movement directly or indirectly controlled a growing body of investment capital and was likely to use its investment leverage to achieve greater influence over the direction of business, Pretorius said.
He said this development coincided with shareholders taking a more active role in the running of companies.

The recently released King report on Corporate Governance pointed out that directors were accountable to shareholders for the performance of the business. But, in the case of firms with a large number of shareholders and no controlling shareholders, directors often enjoyed a virtually free reign due to the passivity of shareholders, Pretorius said.
The report acknowledged "a strongly held view" among retirement fund members that they should participate more actively in the management of companies.
